headline.main: What Story Does Your Personal Data Tell?

docs.abstract: What rules, if any, do you think should govern how companies collect and use personal and aggregate data?
docs.snippet: What rules, if any, do you think should govern how companies collect and use personal and aggregate data?

docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook has swelled to an estimated 845 million users, who typically share everything from their last name to their favorite movies -- even phone numbers and e-mails. What users may not realize is that advertisers then use this information to customize what ads appear on a user's page. What sort of impression do you think advertisers and companies might have of you, based on how you use Facebook and search engines like Google?

headline.main: What Story Does Your Personal Data Tell?

docs.abstract: What rules, if any, do you think should govern how companies collect and use personal and aggregate data?
docs.snippet: What rules, if any, do you think should govern how companies collect and use personal and aggregate data?

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug that scientists had hoped would help prevent breast cancer has a significant side effect.

headline.seo: Exemestane, Thought to Prevent Cancer, Also Causes Bone Loss
headline.main: Cancer-Deterring Drug Found to Harm Bones
headline.print_headline: Cancer-Deterring Drug Found to Harm Bones

docs.abstract: Dr Angela M Cheung study published in journal The Lancet Oncology finds drug exemestane, which was welcomed for its potential to prevent invasive breast cancer in women with higher risk of the disease, poses risk of bone loss.
docs.snippet: A drug that scientists had hoped would help prevent breast cancer has a significant side effect.

docs.abstract: Researchers have found what happens to muscles when a masseur goes to work on them.
docs.snippet: Researchers have found what happens to muscles when a masseur goes to work on them.

docs.lead_paragraph: The city health department’s campaign to jolt New Yorkers out of their bad habits has drawn some criticism for its negative approach.

headline.seo: Some Say New York City Health Ads Should Inspire, Not Scare
headline.main: New York City Defends Health Ads That Frighten the Viewer
headline.print_headline: City Defends Health Ads That Frighten the Viewer

docs.abstract: New York City's health department defends its use of health ads that use graphic images and scenarios to frighten the target audience, tactic that is part of the Bloomberg administration's relentless campaign to jolt New Yorkers out of bad health habits; says use of what has been criticized as a negative approach, is merely stating the hard, cold realities and scientific evidence.
docs.snippet: The city health department’s campaign to jolt New Yorkers out of their bad habits has drawn some criticism for its negative approach.

docs.lead_paragraph: A golden retriever was the only thing that could reach a raging, disconnected boy.

headline.seo: Wonder Dog: A Golden Retriever Reaches a Raging Boy

docs.abstract: Melissa Fay Greene article describes how the family of Iyal Winokur, who struggled to deal with his developmental disabilities due to fetal alcohol syndrome, found relief by enlisting the help of 4 Paws For Ability, a nonprofit corporation that pairs the disabled with service dogs.
docs.snippet: A golden retriever was the only thing that could reach a raging, disconnected boy.
